unnormalised: ## Lights, Camera, FESTIVAL! Why Film Festivals Are More Than Just Red Carpets
normalised: ## Lights, Camera, FESTIVAL! Why Film Festivals Are More Than Just Red Carpets

unnormalised: Hey Bollywood buffs and cinema lovers! Ever wondered where all the *real* movie magic happens outside of the Friday box office rush? I'm talking about film festivals, yaars! They're way more than just fancy premieres and celeb spotting. They're a total celebration of storytelling, culture, and the sheer art of making movies.
normalised: Hey Bollywood buffs and cinema lovers! Ever wondered where all the real movie magic happens outside of the Friday box office rush? I am talking about film festivals, yaars! unnormalised: Think of it this way: it's like a giant Diwali mela, but instead of jalebis, you're feasting on visual treats from all over the world. You get to see films that might never even make it to your local PVR, discover indie gems, and even rub shoulders with the filmmakers themselves.

unnormalised: India's got its own fair share of awesome film festivals. We've got the International Film Festival of India (IFFI) in Goa, which is HUGE and brings in talent from all over the globe. Then there's the Mumbai Film Festival (MAMI), known for showcasing cutting-edge Indian and international cinema. And let’s not forget regional festivals showcasing the richness of Assamese or Marathi cinema!

unnormalised: But why should *you* care? Well, for starters, it's a chance to broaden your horizons. Forget the usual masala flicks (though I love a good SRK romance as much as the next person!). Film festivals expose you to different perspectives, different cultures, and different ways of telling stories. You might discover a whole new genre you never knew you loved!

unnormalised: Plus, it's a fantastic networking opportunity, especially if you're aspiring to be a filmmaker yourself. Imagine getting to chat with a director whose work you admire, or getting feedback on your own short film. Who knows, maybe you'll even get discovered! Think of Anurag Kashyap – his journey itself is like a Bollywood movie!

unnormalised: So, next time a film festival rolls around in your city, ditch the usual Netflix binge and give it a shot. You might just find your new favourite film… or even your calling! And remember to carry cash; sometimes those indie films have their merchandise stalls setup and card machines aren't always reliable! Maybe around Rs. 500 would be a good start. Plus, snacks are important. The halls are probably like 2km from the food stalls. Enjoy the festival, friends!
